problem.p: A function \(f:X\rightarrow Y\) is injective if none of the two different elements in \(X\) are mapped to the same element in \(Y\), which means:\[\forall x_1,x_2\in X,\quad x_1\not= x_2 \quad\Rightarrow\quad f(x_1)\not= f(x_2)\] A function \(f:X\rightarrow Y\) is surjective if all elements in \(Y\) are mapped by at least one element in \(X\), which means:\[\forall y\in Y\quad\exists x\in X,\quad f(x)=y\] For sets \(A = \{1,2,3\}\) and \(B = \{a,b,c,d\}\):

ul.li: How many functions \(f:A\rightarrow B\) are there?
How many functions \(f:B\rightarrow A\) are there?
How many injective functions \(f:A\rightarrow B\) are there?
\(^\ast\) How many surjective functions \(f:B\rightarrow A\) are there?
